Text:
If you can wrap your input with a label, you could do something like this, where you combine pseudo elements with a rotation.

<!-- begin snippet: js hide: false console: true babel: false -->

<!-- language: lang-css -->

    .shadow {
      position: relative;
    }
    .shadow::before,
    .shadow::after {
      content: '';
      position: absolute;
      z-index: -1;
      width: 40%;
      height: 100%;
      top: -5px;
      background: transparent;
      box-shadow: 0px 10px 5px #bbb;
    }
    .shadow::before {
      left: 10%;
      transform: rotate(-5deg);
    }
    .shadow::after {
      right: 10%;
      transform: rotate(5deg);
    }


<!-- language: lang-html -->

    <label class="shadow"><input type="text"></label>


<!-- end snippet -->

If you can wrap your input with a label, you could do something like this, where you combine pseudo elements with a rotation.

<!-- begin snippet: js hide: false console: true babel: false -->

<!-- language: lang-css -->

    .shadow {
      position: relative;
    }
    .shadow::before,
    .shadow::after {
      content: '';
      position: absolute;
      z-index: -1;
      width: 40%;
      height: 100%;
      top: -5px;
      background: transparent;
      box-shadow: 0px 10px 5px #bbb;
    }
    .shadow::before {
      left: 10%;
      transform: rotate(-5deg);
    }
    .shadow::after {
      right: 10%;
      transform: rotate(5deg);
    }


<!-- language: lang-html -->

    <label class="shadow"><input type="text"></label>


<!-- end snippet -->

Here is a 2:nd sample, using gradient

<!-- begin snippet: js hide: false console: true babel: false -->

<!-- language: lang-css -->

    .shadow {
      position: relative;
    }
    .shadow::before,
    .shadow::after {
      content: '';
      position: absolute;
      z-index: -1;
      width: 45%;
      height: 95%;
      top: 6px;
      background: transparent;
      opacity: 0.7;
    }
    .shadow::before {
      left:5%;
      transform: rotate(-5deg);
      background: linear-gradient(to bottom left, rgba(0,0,0,1) 0%,rgba(0,0,0,0) 100%);
    }
    .shadow::after {
      right:5%;
      transform: rotate(5deg);
      background: linear-gradient(to bottom right, rgba(0,0,0,1) 0%,rgba(0,0,0,0) 100%);
    }

<!-- language: lang-html -->

    <label class="shadow"><input type="text"></label>

<!-- end snippet -->

These 2 can of course be combined in many ways to achieve different shadow effects.

With box-shadow one can add several shadows in a row: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18083158/how-to-make-the-new-long-shadow-trend-with-css

With gradient one can use different angles `90deg` instead of `to bottom right` and so on.
